Posts.Content: Just started mine on Monday th is week.   used the cold cap and it was okay, first 10 -,15 mins are the worse.  Early days so far for me, but not too bad, bit low mood ( actually very very weepy)  today, probably  as the steroids have ended.  I haven't felt sick at all so far but took the anti sickness pills. I have been out every day, either to the shop, of to see a friend but also watching lots of telly etc.  Good luck.   nobody day wants to do this.  I would like my old life back,, but  what choice do we have????
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy after double mastectomy

Posts.Content: In think the news about Rio and also with the Sheridan Smith programme tonight, a lot of us ladies may be feeling the same.  I can't get my act together today.   Just feeling low.
Posts.Title: Feeling down today ....

Posts.Content: fybrogel helped me... You can get it from a pharmacy,you could take the fybrogel before chemo if you have trouble keeping things down After, and hopefully you will produce nice squishy stools?
Posts.Title: Endgame!!

Posts.Content: fybrogel helped me... You can get it from a pharmacy,you could take the fybrogel before chemo if you have trouble keeping things down After, and hopefully you will produce nice squishy stools?
Posts.Title: Endgame!!

Posts.Content: Hi... I used cold cap, completed 3 t and 3 FEC.  I lost some hair but not enough that anyone noticed.  it worked fine for me.  just make sure it is as tight fitting as possible and loads of conditioner.  it  doesn't work for everyone, but you may consider it worth a try.
Posts.Title: fec-t and cold cap

Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy and immediate reconstruction in August last year.  I had a port put in so that, in time, they can inflate my implant to match my other breast.  However the skill of my surgeon ensured that my new breast matched the other.  I feel sure that once it has properly settled (and after the effacts of radiotherapy) she may want to make adjustments,  but if she doesn't.... I'm quite happy.  They have done a fabulous job. And you would never know in clothes or underwear.  I'm Very grateful to the NHS.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy and immediate reconstruction in August last year.  I had a port put in so that, in time, they can inflate my implant to match my other breast.  However the skill of my surgeon ensured that my new breast matched the other.  I feel sure that once it has properly settled (and after the effacts of radiotherapy) she may want to make adjustments,  but if she doesn't.... I'm quite happy.  They have done a fabulous job. And you would never know in clothes or underwear.  I'm Very grateful to the NHS.
Posts.Title: Reconstruction surgery

Posts.Content: So nice to hear a positive story, specially from someone way down the road....people keep saying how quick it goes but I have yet to be convinced.  Thank you.
Posts.Title: HAIR AFTER CHEMO !!

Posts.Content: Hi, Following the conversations with Snizzle et al re sentinel nodes,  I have become very anxious again.... I know I have at least  three positive nodes, and am expecting to have axilllary clearance! When In have mastectomy - which I think  means all my nodes including sentinel one removed.   However if it is in my sentinel node does this mean I have a much  higher rate or reoccurence?  not sure I want to know the answer ..
Posts.Title: Sentinel node - what is it exactly????

Posts.Content: Thank you.   I had a bubble test, and because it didn't work properly they took out 5 nodes and 3were positive.  i am having chemo and will have ax clearance so what you say us really helpful.  I think I understand and something comes up and  then I'm not sure. Thanks. H
Posts.Title: Sentinel node - what is it exactly????

Posts.Content: Words of wisdom there... Thanks.
Posts.Title: Sentinel node - what is it exactly????

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissie T was no nastier for me than FEC.... In fact I think FEC has been a little more harsh, so wishing you well. X
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Dear Chrissie Oh those  meltdowns..... my  man is not alone in the " wet shoulder" group then...... For me they  are nearly always in first week after chemo. That stuff plays with your head.  Does this mean I am normal???.  really???     hope you feel better soon xxxxx
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi there, there are many if us going through this course  of treatment, although not  necessarily in the same order.    There is a very active "June Chemo Club" .. A club you would never want to join , but there is loads of support and  advice on there,  and jokes too. Seems you might fit the timescale to join. You can ask absolutely anything, nobody cares what you may ask, there are no stupid questions and you can always ask privately if you prefer It that way.   They are  a great bunch of people  helping each other through one of the toughest times.  There is also an " under 50s group.  Have a look and see what you think Hx
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi there again,  I had my hair cut short before I did the cold cap, but if you want to keep your long hair there are some young girls who have long hair and have managed to keep theirs who are having  chemo at the same time as me. just thought you might like to know.  I am sad to  to hear about you  fertility treatment.   May I wish you everything you wish for yourselves and you get all the support you need with this.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Try seasalt....they do a nice line in buffs... I found them useful, not too hot and they stay on!!
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: It was a bit nice!!!!   And it was so cold in there again today until they turned off the air con... Now the appts are flooding in for surgeons, plastics, ultrasound, chemo effects check....... Etc etc.   op and recon(?) in approx 4 weeks date to be confirmed... So am going to make the  most of feel good days  between now and then. Think we might leave the  caravan in Sheringham park in Norfolk.  A few beach walks,   Fish and chips on the Pier at cromer, mooching round Wells, crabbing with grandaughter at Blakeney..  That'll do it.   Maybe even a crab sandwich in a bit later on ...
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Lecture me all you like,  good advice always welcome.  although at the moment I'm doing a lot of resting post las FEC!!!  Should feel better soon.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: And what food does he recommend??
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Wouldn't it be great if we could all take the time off that we need with no financial pressure.  But if you don't get paid While off sick it can be so stressful and damaging in so many ways.   what do you do???.  I couldnt have worked through chemo all the time, some days yes but not all the time.m
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Yes, problems with my eyes, just running and running, and if I looked  down my glasses lens filled with  water!  I wore a scarf and kept wiping!!! YUCK!   I shall think of you on Tuesday, and wish you well.  That's a toughie.  X
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: And can I Also add, as another cold cap wearer, that  I have lost hair on the top of my head only, so opt for a buff or a beret that when you are having FEC it adds two hours on after the chemo is finished, but witH T adds on just 45 mins... which may be at the same time as they are putting saline through the drip... good luck
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Chemo done Hello Bunnies I've finished it,  I've completed my chemo. No. 6 (FEC)done this morning.  lovely chemo nurse who herself had breast cancer 8 years ago, she is clearly doing well. To all those of you starting out... I thought I could not do this at the beginning.  But 19 weeks later I have , with tears and tantrums and highs ..It passes and surprisingly quickly - Geroge  said that but there was a point  when I could  not believe him.  But he was right.  So have faith , you too will get there So still op and rads to go so not over yet...  But  pleased this bit is done.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi you, I am doing the same regime as your mum.... it has been harder with FEC  for me although some find it Easier.  It may be because of the build up over the 18 weeks, but I have found the problems are nausea, ( lots of anti nausea meds)  extreme tiredness, taste buds completely shot and can only drink squash or ginger beer, constipation.  However by day 8 - 9 I have felt better and last week felt really good and full of beans until the final infusion last Friday.   I hope she copes well. I am glad mine is over ... ..
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: It sometimes feels like that, and it can be really hard on us when plans change or are in doubt or there are time delays.  I have got very despondent over these things, and worried too.  However difficult it is we somehow have to just get our heads round it all and go with it, and chemo will happen but they won't give if to you if you have an infection - it could make you very very Ill.  It is a testing time but you will get there.    No idea about your supplements, unless they react  with something else???.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Question????   Any of you gals that have had reconstruction, particularly LD flap??  How long before you can batH Or shower ????   Approx....   And swimming in a pool???
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi,  I presume you mean reconstruction???   I had this done three weeks ago, and there are plenty of ladies who have also had this done in one form or anotheR.   Ask away and have a look through the older threads - loads of info and knowledoge and experiences on here.
Posts.Title: breast replacement surgery

Posts.Content: How horrid for you... And scary.  I have tummy injections for 10 days after chemo, my husband does them for me .  I think they can cause aches and pains as the bone marrow works overtime .  I'my sure we all have a cry sometimes and feel low.  and then we have good days, But a cry and a scream and a rant are normal.. particularly when our spirits are low  - and chemo plays with the mind as well as the body!
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi ,   I don't like FEC, think it's slightly worse than Tax.... Bu doable.  I felt   rough and low last week but am now on second week and  feeling pretty good.   And as for cold  cap,  I still have hair, it is thinner and the FEC has affected my hair more than the T , but I guess I have about 70% of my hair and the  thin stuff is on the top of my head so I just wear a little beret.  fringe sides and back are good. Eyebrows looking very very thin this morning, so they have  done well, but a shame they're giving up just before the last one but I'm fine with that. Was it worth the cold cap??? For me , yes it was, although I was a bit freaked  by the extra time after chemo with FEC. ( two hours - only 45 mins with T. ).    Hope everyone is okay. XXXX
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Nadjie....  You're mad as a box of frogs.  A very very brave feisty box of frogs and I really wish you well with that.  I don't know how you can even contemplate it....It takes me two hours to make a cup of tea on a bad day!!,  Kazza..  I have the same as you and I shall be on tamoxifen for 10 years Anyone considering the cold cap... I saved about70% of mine. I have very fine fluff on my legs! and some very fine grey  fluff on my head where I have lost some.   I saw the surgeons yesterday and I have decided on immediate reconstruction, will have an implant but because that will be protected by my moved back muscle I can have an implant despite planned radiotherapy.  No tummy surgery as I have no fat there . But my muscles are good it seems. Also full node clearance.  Provisional date of 28 July.   They suggested a few days holiday before then.  Be Rude Not To.  To  everyone having a horrid time or just starting out..... It does go by.  Sometimes it seemed (to me anyway) too big a mountain, but step by step we get there.  Even a complete wuss like me. X
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: i hate  that word too... If I had chosen to do this I would be brave.  But i didn't choose to do this... and completely agree, we have no choice.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: I understand the envy... Felt the same way about others .... It's natural as we all want to be finished and well more than anything else. .... I don't have any questions as yet as you have already been so helpful but I will message you when I do.  But it very much apoears to be heading that way, although I am quite a lot scared but if others can do it.....
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: I hadn't even thought about asking re physio...  How silly  am I??.   I will ask during my many appts  over the  next week or so.   That's  really helpful Advice.  And I will look into what else is available .  I too am very active  usually, and quite fit so I will want to get my fitness back.  I think I will have such a shock when I dance again, but I can ease myself back in gently to start, and dance and music so very  very good for mental health.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi chrissie, What a pain, but according to my Onc they can come up quite quickly, within a couple of days so I do hope you'll be okay.  It horrid not to know for sure though.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Kazza -Hope you feel better very soon.  Just had a  friend come round who had a dreadful time with chemo and was very ill.  She had her surgery and  lymph node clearance  done about 3months ago, three weeks after chemo.    What a lovely pair she has... and barely any visible scarring.  Full Mobility, back at work, grey hair ( but not for long) ... Looks fab, feels fab.  Just thought I'd share....
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Provisional date 28 July
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi,  the advice to me was not to take tablets as they may disguise an infection, by lowering any  possible temperature but to only take them as and when necessarY, but making sure your temperature is normal before taking them. I was lucky and had no pain from T so perhaps it is easy for me to say tHat.   But pain is not inevitable.  I felt pretty shite for days 3, 4, 5, and then gradually got better.   Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi kazza ... Did you get those injections with FEC as well? I am having them..... So pleased to hear the double decker hasn't come along yet, Perhaps it will be a moped!
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Lee Half foo foo here.. ( sorry again George - perhaps you could find an appropriate ditty for us)... But just to hopefully reassure you, I found that where my scalp was tender was where the hair thinned.  This lasted for a few days then stopped.  I Didn't lose much hair on the T at all And kept  my eyebrows  until I started the FEC.   Kept one moustache hair all the way through .  Proud of that one!
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Kazza, i lost my sense of taste and had a sore mouth on T no 1... But not with 2 and3 -well not as much anyway.  Tiredness was a problem ,but I. have found that worse with FEC,  Although I am feeling pretty good right now and all this week!   I did find days 4 - 8 or thereabouts worse with T and then it lifted and I felt normal for a week or more till next one.  So you should feel better soon. Good luckxxxx
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi, I have had this every time, and it took 3-4 weeks to feel better. but times do vary.  I found it helped to keep it stretched when possible and to gently manoeuvre it.   i don't think it is lasting and the veins do recover
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: I adore Norfolk, such good  times there all of my life, and near enough for me (just n of cambridge) to come and go - so seems a reasonable plan.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: They  usually do improve quickly, but if not they will do it next week.  It happened to me on no 5 and I was devastated, mind you I had taken all the pills and had the saline drip and cold cap and been there for two plus hours and at the point of infusion they actually checked my bloods and sent me home.  It was horrid.... But it's better to wait a week than be very ill.  but I understand how  are feeling.  You will get there.  I have just  finished and you will too.   hope it goes well x
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi you, is this your first tummy Injection?  Is it the GCSF???.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissiie - The FEC was much harder then the T on my hair.... I think you can decide about reconstruction or not for some years  afterward so there is no pressure to do anything at all in a hurry.  it is a very personal choice... I have been  here since March... But there was no March chemo Club.... So I snuck in to the next one!
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: Hi Chrissie Im not art all keen on the back flap either.....and it is a longer recovery.   BUT ... i know four women who have had this done at Addenbrookes and the results have been fantastic.  I have had sneak  previews and I want to look like them.  and they are all very active fit people.  I think the biggest worry for me long term (apart from the obvious) is the  lymph node removal and possible consequences... .. But I can't change that. But it takes time and talking to people to make a decision that is right for you.  Just hope I'm not proved wrong,  best not ask me in the days after the op!
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: I Agree totally.  It's the difference between deciding to lose your hair...of having no choice at all... Alongside the  treatment and the fear.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Content: Alright to prcticeon .....!
Posts.Title: There's light at the end of the tunnel, ladies...

Posts.Content: I found my decision changed as I went through treatment.   I opted for flat at first, just cos it's easier, but the girls on here really helped me to make a different decision.  But different strokes.....
Posts.Title: Bra recommendation, post surgery

Posts.Content: I hAd a mastectomy and recon last week.   My surgeon was quite specific about the bra (maybe different for you as you have not mentioned recon) and I went to John lewis.  I also bought a couple from m and s and when I took them in to hospital they were discarded by BCN immediately.     The staff at John Lewis were very helpful. I would recommend buying some bra expanders regardless of where you go, they have been very useful as I was swollen after the op, and I could reduce the size of my bra as the swelling went down. Hope this helps.  Hx
Posts.Title: Bra recommendation, post surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I have had the clip done - I was surprised as it didn't hurt , they give you a local anaesthetic and no problems afterward.  Hope this is a little reassuring.
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy result

Posts.Content: Hi Deebee,  three weeks since my diagnosis.  having this test and that test, trying to learn how to cope, mind races ahead, then goes into overdrive.   people say be positive.....  Well I ain't succeeding at that one yet.   Waiting for mastectomy date. I am at Addenbrookes, Cambridge.  it is hard, and I'm not yet sure if these forums help.   Early days for me, but my family is fab, my husband is the best....  Scary stuff.  it's a mess. I think we probably all have to learn to deal with it in our own way.    Ill let you know when I have some peace of mind!
Posts.Title: feeling sad angry lonely and lots more

Posts.Content: Hi I never thought of this as a site to promote any one treatment.   Surely it is a site for us to share our thoughts, feelings fears etc without fear of judgement. Chloecat is not saying we should choose her route - she is just explaining what she is doing.  We are all affected by cancer one way or the other and we all have different ways of dealing with it.  We are all vulnerable and sometimes scared.  I chose conventional treatment.  I wouldn't / couldn't do what Chloecat is doing for numerous reasons,  but it is her right to choose her own path - and she should not be criticised for sharing her views and experiences.  Can we not listen, make our own decisions and agree to agreeably disagree?????
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Dear Chloecat...I have been watching your posts for some time... I so admire your courage in choosing your own treatment route..Just wanted to say about Letrozole... I have been taking it for nearly a year and apart from a few hot flushes which have been very bearable it has been fine.  It obviously varies from person to person and nobody know how it will affect you, but it is not always as bad as you might think..  Much love X
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Just had a reconstruction from my own skin 3 weeks ago.  Very painless as there are no nerves left.  So far no problems, dressings come off on 20th, and colour will be improved by tattoo.  But looks good, although something of a huge nipple.  I am assured it will shrink.  I wasn't sure about it but it does make me feel more complete.  Like the treatment has finished with a cherry on the top!  HOpefully.
Posts.Title: Nipple reconstruction....or not?

Posts.Content: Hi,  All I know about this scenario is that my friends mum had this and they never found the primary source.  she had chemo and rads but no op as there was no tumour.  she is fine now, 5 years on.  X
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Thanks for this, that is great to hear.  Perhaps I shall be able to prevent a complete meltdown on my part,  it is clear that everyone's experiences are different on here,  and we all seem to find our own way through this.  But as for chemo, I have used the cold cap athough I have a wig Ready and waiting ,After two sessions it has worked so far......  i lost some of the top of my head but no bald patches.  It is time consuming, - more time in the chemo unit, may not be for you.  It is not nice for the first 15 mins and then it is fine, the strap under the jaw is worse than the cold. But several of us are using it at Addenbrookes, and it seems to be successful so far. Just thought you might like to hear my view,  other ladies seem to happily embrace the baldness.  I so admire them.
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: I think it's impossible to say whether your hIr loss will continue.  But I used the cold cap,and lost some hair ... But I found the sore area you mention was the area where I lost hair, it was the hair follicles makong protests before they fell out.  Having said that I kept enough hair for nobody to notice the hair loss.  8 weeks after the end of chemo the hair is coming back ( grey) but I also seem to be shedding the longer hair.  Not sure why or if that will continue???
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: BUT wanting to die is a temporary state of mind.   It will pass. X
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi. Im having chemo first and then mastectomy...  Chemo is not nice, and up has made feel rough for some days and then I pick up.  there are a whole list of side effects, but you shouldn't get them All.  I have found it surprisingly doable. the worst thing for me has been the foggy brain, and the tiredness.  but both have lifted.  I was utterly terrified, just like you. However I am really worried about my mastectomy later on.... Absolutely terrified  about that!   We are all afraid I think,
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: Thanks for this, that is great to hear.  Perhaps I shall be able to prevent a complete meltdown on my part,  it is clear that everyone's experiences are different on here,  and we all seem to find our own way through this.  But as for chemo, I have used the cold cap athough I have a wig Ready and waiting ,After two sessions it has worked so far......  i lost some of the top of my head but no bald patches.  It is time consuming, - more time in the chemo unit, may not be for you.  It is not nice for the first 15 mins and then it is fine, the strap under the jaw is worse than the cold. But several of us are using it at Addenbrookes, and it seems to be successful so far. Just thought you might like to hear my view,  other ladies seem to happily embrace the baldness.  I so admire them.
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: Hi. Im having chemo first and then mastectomy...  Chemo is not nice, and up has made feel rough for some days and then I pick up.  there are a whole list of side effects, but you shouldn't get them All.  I have found it surprisingly doable. the worst thing for me has been the foggy brain, and the tiredness.  but both have lifted.  I was utterly terrified, just like you. However I am really worried about my mastectomy later on.... Absolutely terrified  about that!   We are all afraid I think,
Posts.Title: not having a good day :(

Posts.Content: Hi, the whole thing is scary, particularly heading into the unknown.  And we all have  different experiences of chemo, some seem to sail through, others don't do any sailing at all.  Most of us just get through some poorly days and make the most of the good ones.  But having finished chemo now I would say that it is not nice, it is nowhere near as bad as I expected but it is doable.  And my hospital and GP were very responsive and efficient when I had a concern.    As for dogs,   I have 5 and they were just fine.  Just washed my hands after touching them, certainly not allowed on beds /settees (as usual anyway).  But mine are not so boisterous.    Wishing you well. X
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: www.act4addenbrookes.org.uk/bracode.. This is about the new research currently being undertaken at Addenbrookes to ensure treatment for men and women with BC is appropriiate and necessary.   It could, in time, change the way we are treated.  Https://youtu.be/rX7u5rW-OuQ
Posts.Title: You may have seen this , but it is worth a look ..

Posts.Content: YAY!!!!!   What a relief for you
Posts.Title: Please help me ( I need advice regarding reconstruction being cancelled...

Posts.Content: I used the cold cap.. It was worth it for me.  If you go,through July chemo club there is lots of information, but happy to answer any questions.  But I would advise loads and loads of conditioner and try to make sure the cap fits as tightly as is possible.  Not pleasant , but okay after the first 10 mins.  I didn't suffer from headaches at all, but I. Know some people do.
Posts.Title: Cold Caps

Posts.Content: Hi, I haven't had my op   yet, But I have 5 lymph nodes removed under local For testing,... Once the local wore off it was very very painful for a few hours and was tender and quite painful  for several weeks.  The bruising lasted for a couple of months. it will get better, over time.
Posts.Title: breast dancer er positive

Posts.Content: I have  been to breast clinic at Addenbrookes today for pre chemo checks and  ultrasound.  Got chatting to a lady who I guessed was about 70 years old.  Diagnosed in 1973, had radiotherapy as chemo was not around then .  She is actually 87 years old and still has yearly check ups!   Ain't that just grand????
Posts.Title: Positive news

Posts.Content: I had a left mastectomy with immediate reconstruction in August 2015 via back muscle and an implant,  not enough fat on my tummy to make a big enough breast so implant was used.  I also had radiotherapy but my surgeon was happy that the RT would not affect the implant. ( Addenbrookes)  I had 5 drains, they were very uncomfy, the ANC was by far the worst bit.  After the first 48 hours I got by on paracetamol and ibuprofen and  was back to driving after 5 weeks.  I did my exercises religiously, and although there is a faint awareness of the surgery, I rarely give the reconstruction a thought.  It all feels great and soft and moves naturally. .   And you can't tell with my bra  on, and I feel fine and well.  IT was a tough old road and I never thought I would get here.  I was such a wimp. But here I am. Enjoying my life. X
Posts.Title: Prophylactic mastectomy with tissue expander and implants... Advice...

Posts.Content: Glad you had it drained and that bit is okay.   I haven't got cording or an infection and am still sore  mostly on my back and new boob.  Impatience plays a big part too.   I am wanting to do stuff, and I just  cant at the moment.   So we just have to potter around nd wait for it all to heal I guess.    And a good cry is sometimes needed ....
Posts.Title: Seroma and infection.

Posts.Content: Hi. I have to agree with Crystal kitty - that came up on my   FB. Page and since then a further  three negative posts about BC - well I.didn't watch the third one as I was feeling " enough, piss off".   It seems to me that raising awareness always involves negative stories, and I know several people who had BC years and years ago (20years plus) and are fine.  and several recently diagnosed people who are also fine and hopefully remain so,  The negative stories terrify me.   I can fully understand why, when treatment is finished, you perhaps don't want to post, blog etc.  But it might reassure those of us going through treatment if perhaps they could just post something a little bit positive.
Posts.Title: Is it just me ...

Posts.Content: In my case  I am looking at losing  a boob on my 60th.  I was feeling miserable about that, but perhaps I should look at it as hopefully receiving the gift of health.... Thank you ladies. and I can have my 60th another day!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy on my birthday...what a present!

Posts.Content: HI there.  I had chemo, mastectomy and immediate reconstruction with implant ( no fat on tummy and thigh fat is no good)  and lymph node clearance, radiotherapy.     Four weeks ago I had nipple reconstruction, from my own skin.  My plastic surgeon (Addenbrookes) told me that I would not be able to see the difference between my two breasts when she had finished with me.... And I can't.  They are both the same apart from the colour of the new nipple which she will complete with tattoo to colour it in a couple of weeks.  THe  reconstruction was done under local, although there is no feeling in my new breast anyway... All healed up fine.  It's not for everyone, I wasn't sure I could be bothered as I was actually reasonably happy with no nipple.  But it has made an unexpected difference to the way I feel about myself.  Off to Lanzarote next week and have no problem with skimpy tops etc.   Please PM me if you want a  picture.  I too am single now.  and that's a whole other challenge after breastcancer... Haven't got my head round that yet.  Although I have been on several dates ... And I told some of the men and they still wanted to see me again.  Shame I didn't feel the same way!   IF at first you don't succeed......
Posts.Title: Just joined the roller coaster - help !

Posts.Content: It is all very scary.  Especially at first.  I have done chemo (yay!) and now waiting for op in two weeks. ( Eeek!)..    I was a jibbering wreck at time of diagnosis,  Now I Am not.  I have moments of doubt, of uncertainty, but I have faith and confidence in the medics at Addenbrokes. And lots of support from the wonderful women on here ( and George with his depth of knowledge and his calming sensible words of wisdom) .  You too will reach this point.  It is not easy, some suffer from side effects more than others, but believe me, if I can get this far,  so can you.   Mind you, don't contact me for the first couple of days after the op.... ( mastectomy and reconstruction and node clearance) I may be grumpy, bad tempered and generallY an utter arse!
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: It was in order to shrink the tumour before op.  I had T first and then FEC.  I have lobular cancer , which is more difficult to detect.   As for reconstruction. It is a personal Decision. And you can always have reconstruction at a later date .  My decision was to get it all over and done with.  Imalso have several friends ( and it is surprising how many of us are out there)  who have had the L D flap reconstruction, and the results have been fntastiic.  But my first instinct was not to bother with reconstruction and you can review your decision at any time.  as I did.  Hopie this helps but feel free to ask any questions, both now and later.  you can always message me privately if it is very personal.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed yesterday - need mastectomy August 19th :-O

Posts.Content: In my case  I am looking at losing  a boob on my 60th.  I was feeling miserable about that, but perhaps I should look at it as hopefully receiving the gift of health.... Thank you ladies. and I can have my 60th another day!
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy on my birthday...what a present!

Posts.Content: I think the problem is that people who have recovered from breast cancer don't want / need to post.  Those of us at are going through it are hearing only the problems / concerns. ... Because when I am scared / worried I look at the sites.  I look too much and need to Stop it. I would love to hear positive stories.  But I do have two friends (both dancers - and I dance too)  both have  had a mastectomy and reconstruction and they are so athletic and wear little tops and you would not know.  They have scars, , mentally and physically but they just love life. They look fabulous on the dance floor - and in normal life too. I just hope I can move like them eventually, one is 4 years on,  the other had her treatment 2014.  Bu even if I cannot move like that I will just do ballroom instead!  Or something else together. But they don't post.  They are done with cancer, although they do help people like me.
Posts.Title: Positive outcomes ...

Posts.Content: I have sent you  a friend  request.  Happy to ask my friends if they would be interested in participating.  I know a few people who are okay, many years later.  Sometimes I feel confident , other times not  so much.   I suspect everyone is the same?.

Posts.Content: try again?????
